data.name: DIY ActiveRecord a.k.a KataRecord
data.description:
Those warriors who worked with Ruby on Rails are familiar with ActiveRecord.
Rails is built on MVC pattern where M stands for Model. Model describes an entity which has a corresponding table in database. ActiveRecord is actually ORM library. And today - you're going to build your own... kind of.

We are going to use not a real database but an imitation. There are two `Hashes` prepared for you: `DB` and `DB_SCHEMA`. The first one is our "Database" while the second will serve as a definition of "tables" and "columns" there (a.k.a `schema.rb`).

Here is and example of database and it's schema after creating `Person` model and a corresponding table. 


````ruby
DB_SCHEMA = { person: [:id, :name, :address] } # our "DB schema"
DB = { person: [] } # "DB" itself
````


_**For the sake of simplicity we:**_

- Do not mess with table name pluralization. Person model will have "person" table.
- Do not care about data types.

**All the required code to "create tables" is handled by kata.**

Your job is to create a class `KataRecord` which will be our kind-of ORM and give any of its' subclasses these abilites:

- create instance of model from parameters `Hash`. Note that you should only pass parameters that exist in this model's DB schema entry. You should also raise exception if provided argument is not a `Hash`.
- get and set entity attributes using methods named after these attributes (ex: `person.name`, `person.name = "Warrior"`
- find record by id (every Model will have id as a "primary key") using `find(id)` method. Keep in mind that 1st record should have ID == 1 or at least pretend to.
- find record by any other attribute name using corresponding method (ex: Person has name so we can use `find_by_name(name)` method)
- save record to database with autoincrementing ID
- delete record from database

Good luck!
